citeinfo.title: GPS Location Data from Female Polar Bears (Ursus maritimus) Instrumented in the Southern Beaufort Sea with Video Camera Collars equipped with Satellite-linked GPS Receivers by the USGS in April 2014-2016

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.othercit: Suggested citation: Pagano, Anthony M., 2018, GPS Location Data from Female Polar Bears (Ursus maritimus) Instrumented in the Southern Beaufort Sea with Video Camera Collars equipped with Satellite-linked Transmitters by the USGS in April 2014-2016: U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F7XW4H0P.

citeinfo.origin: USGS Alaska Science Center, Polar Bear Research Program
citeinfo.title: Changing Arctic Ecosystems: The effects of declining sea ice on polar bear behaviors and energetic rates

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

descript.abstract: This dataset contains GPS locations collected by satellite-linked GPS receivers on collars attached to 9 female polar bears that were instrumented in the southern Beaufort Sea in April 2014-2016.
descript.purpose: These data were collected to gain insights into the spring movement patterns of female polar bears without dependent young in the southern Beaufort Sea.

theme.themekt: NASA GCMD Earth Science Keywords Thesaurus

idinfo.useconst: For purposes of publication or dissemination, citations or credit should be given to the author and the U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center. It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data to evaluate limitations, restrictions or intended use.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.title: High-energy, high-fat lifestyle challenges an Arctic apex predator, the polar bear

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted.

dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented. Instances in which the GPS failed to record a fix are denoted by N/A.

horizpa.horizpar: Transmitter locations were determined by the processing of the global positioning system onboard the transmitter with accuracy of < 30 m.

method.methdesc: Receivers recorded global positioning system (GPS) location fixes every 5, 10, or 30 minutes and stored locations into internal memory before being uploaded upon collar recovery.

citeinfo.origin: Tomkiewicz, S., M.R. Fuller, J.G. Kie, and K.K. Bates
citeinfo.title: Global positioning system and associated technologies in animal behaviour and ecological research

pubinfo.publish: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B

procstep.procdesc: We collected GPS satellite telemetry locations from 9 female polar bears without dependent young in April 2014-2016.

enttyp.enttypd: GPS locations of 9 female polar bears in the southern Beaufort Sea in April 2014-2016

attr.attrdef: The date (dd.mm.yyyy) the GPS location was obtained in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).
The time (hh:mm:ss) the GPS location was obtained in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).
The latitude measurement from a satellite-linked GPS receiver. N/A indicates the GPS failed to record a latitudinal fix.
The longitude measurement from a satellite-linked GPS receiver. N/A indicates the GPS failed to record a longitudinal fix.
